title: How Does the World’s Largest Seabird Know Where to Fly?
intro: Wandering albatrosses navigate thousands of miles using “the voice of the sea.”

transcript.author: Joseph Polidoro
transcript.text: Imagine for a moment that you’re a very hungry bird soaring over 30-foot ocean swells in high winds, with no land for thousands of miles. How do you know where you’re going? If you’re a wandering albatross, you listen.  [CLIP: Music] According to a new finding in October’s Proceedings of the National Association of Sciences USA, this seabird navigates using sounds below our thresholds for hearing. For Science, Quickly, I’m Joseph Polidoro.

transcript.author: Joseph Polidoro
transcript.text: The wandering albatross thrives in the circumpolar band of ocean north of Antarctica—a windswept region that the world’s best sailors say has the most inhospitable seas on the planet. On the Southern Ocean’s islands where they nest and brood, one wandering albatross parent tends the nest while its partner takes to the sea, traveling as much as 10,000 kilometers as it forages for scattered prey. The bird must eat enough to fuel its turn on the nest, which can be a long time ...

transcript.author: Samantha Patrick
transcript.text: Birds might go for, perhaps, a minimum of four or five days, up to 30 days.

transcript.author: Polidoro
transcript.text: Samantha Patrick is a marine ecologist at the University of Liverpool in England and a co-author of the study. Wandering albatrosses actually gain weight on these long trips because they’re extremely efficient flyers.

transcript.author: Sophie de Grissac
transcript.text: It almost never beats its wings. It’s quite fascinating to see them flying in the winds. When they’re flying, their heartbeat is the same as when they’re resting.

transcript.author: Polidoro
transcript.text: That’s Sophie de Grissac, an ornithologist and a researcher at the French National Museum of Natural History in Paris, who wasn’t involved in the study. With their long wingspan—the longest of any bird, maxing out at nearly 12 feet—wandering albatrosses use wind, air pressure gradients, and gravity above the swells and waves to soar for thousands of miles, reaching top speeds of 45 miles an hour. Basically, wandering albatrosses don’t fly. They soar.

transcript.author: De Grissac
transcript.text: The more distance you cover, the more you may find food.

transcript.author: Polidoro
transcript.text: The wandering albatross’s keen senses of sight and smell help it locate prey. But these senses are good for about 100 kilometers—a distance the bird can travel in as little as an hour and a half. So how does the albatross know where to soar toward?

transcript.text: There does seem to be this large gap in information that they’re able to access.

transcript.author: Polidoro
transcript.text: A clue came in a chance encounter on the way to the Crozet Islands, part of the French Southern and Antarctic Territories, where Patrick was headed to study albatrosses.

transcript.author: Patrick
transcript.text: On the same vessel were some researchers from the [United Nations]. They were going to work with the hydrophone station that’s used to monitor nuclear tests. It also gathers infrasound data. And we came up with the question of whether seabirds could use infrasound. And it was clear that no one had really thought about this before, and that’s where the idea for the project came from.

transcript.author: Polidoro
transcript.text: Infrasound is any sound below 20 hertz, where human hearing starts to drop off. At the very low end of the infrasound spectrum are microbaroms—very low-frequency sounds between 0.1 and 0.6 Hz that are detectable across thousands of miles.

transcript.author: Polidoro
transcript.text: Natasha Gillies is a seabird ecologist at the University of Liverpool and a co-author of the study. The constant hum of microbarom infrasound is called “the voice of the sea.” It’s present everywhere, all the time. But it’s unevenly distributed.

transcript.author: Gillies
transcript.text: Where you have more energy in the ocean system because you have wavier areas or windy areas, then you get louder microbarom regions.

transcript.author: Polidoro
transcript.text: Ideal soaring conditions for wandering albatrosses.

transcript.author: Patrick
transcript.text: But it also gives them information about standing ocean waves, and this is often caused by things like storms. transcript.text: So essentially what we can get is: if you put an albatross at point X in space and on this day in time, what infrasound would it be likely to hear and experience?
